item.title: Students Express: share your spoken word videos
item.trailText: Young people and students: we’d like to see your spoken word videos on the theme of heat
item.standFirst: Young people and students: we’d like to see your spoken word videos on the theme of heat
item.body:
Here at Guardian Students, we aim to provide a platform for a wide range of student and young voices. Students use our Blogging Students section to talk about everything from school feminist societies to spiked drinks.

But we know that not all young people are writers by nature. While you may have plenty to say, you might not want to express it through carefully crafted blogs. That’s why we’ve launched Students Express – a new way for you to showcase your work on the Guardian. We’ll be inviting submissions around a variety of themes and plan to compile some of the best ones into galleries and articles on the Guardian site.

This week, we’re asking you to submit your spoken word videos. With today being the hottest day of the year, why not show us your performances on the theme of “heat”?

What we’re looking for

  • Spoken word videos on the theme of “heat”. You could also send in a written poem or extract. Interpret the word as you like; maybe you’re inspired to write about the weather, your emotions, politics, or something else; anything goes.
  • Poetry, spoken word and creative writing that doesn’t fit the theme and not by young people and students will also be approved.

If you need some inspiration here are some of the videos we received on GuardianWitness last time we ran a spoken word assignment:

How to submit your work

Submit your work through GuardianWitness – it’s really straightforward. You can share your work by clicking on the blue “Contribute” button on this article. You can also use the GuardianWitness smartphone app or the Guardian app and search for “GuardianWitness assignments”. If you’re on Facebook, Twitter or Instagram you can share your art using #guardianstudents.

Alongside your entry, let us know your name, educational instituion and what you are currently studying.

cards.title: Ten years on from 7/7 / Share your memories

item.title: 7/7 10 years on: share your memories
item.trailText: Even if you weren’t directly affected by the shocking events of 7 July 2005, many will remember that day. Share your memories via GuardianWitness
item.standFirst: Even if you weren’t directly affected by the shocking events of 7 July 2005, many will remember that day. Share your memories via GuardianWitness
item.body:
It is now ten years since four bombs were detonated in London during rush hour, killing 52 and injuring more than 700. Even if you weren’t in London that day the scale and effect of the attacks had a huge impact across the UK.

Whether you were in London or elsewhere, we’d like to hear your memories of that day. How did you find out about the events? Did you follow the live news coverage? Were you personally affected by the attacks? Perhaps you were also in London that morning – or were anxious about relatives and friends? Was there any lasting impact?

Share your memories and stories and we’ll use the most interesting contributions in our reporting.

You can share your memories with GuardianWitness by clicking on the blue ‘Contribute’ buttons on this article. You can also use the GuardianWitness smartphone app or the Guardian app and search for ‘GuardianWitness assignments.’

cards.title: Q&A / How can aid funding be more transparent? - as it happened
cards.rawTitle: How can aid funding be more transparent? - as it happened

item.title: Live Q&A: how can aid funding be more transparent?
item.trailText: Taxpayers have a right to know where their money goes, so what’s the best way to inform them? Join a panel of experts on Thursday 2 July, 1–3pm BST, to discuss
item.standFirst: Taxpayers have a right to know where their money goes, so what’s the best way to inform them? Join a panel of experts on Thursday 2 July, 1–3pm BST, to discuss
item.body:
Where does the money we give our favourite charities actually go? What about aid from national governments? Who ends up getting hold of that?

For years the way donations were dished out by aid organisations and states in the developing world was cloaked in secrecy. Despite some moves to improve transparency, including the Aid Transparency Index, GuideStar and the International Aid Transparency Initiative; there’s still a way to go.

Related: Has the aid transparency standard come of age?

Earlier this month, the Independent Commission for Aid Impact published a report which criticised the UK’s Department for International Development for a lack of transparency in the way it funnels billions of pounds of taxpayers’ money through multilateral organisations like the EU, the UN and the World Bank.

During the recent relief response to the Nepal earthquake, aid agencies faced a slew of stories in the international media calling for clarity about where the money was going in a country where corruption is said to be “endemic”.

But in the midst of a disaster, is it ever possible to keep a clear track of funds? How can the transparency initiatives already out there be more effective? And how can governments be more open about where taxpayers’ money ends up?

Join an expert panel on Thursday 2 July, 1–3pm BST, to discuss these questions and more.

The live chat is not video or audio-enabled but will take place in the comments section (below). Get in touch via globaldevpros@theguardian.com or @GuardianGDP on Twitter to recommend someone for our expert panel. Follow the discussion using the hashtag #globaldevlive.

The panel

Hamzat Lawal, co-founder, Follow The Money, Abuja, Nigeria @Hamzy12
Hamzat leads a team of data analysts, campaigners and journalists using technology to advocate, track and visualise funds meant for local communities.

Vijaya Ramachandran, senior fellow, Center for Global Development, Washington, DC, USA @vijramachandran
Vijaya writes on the need for transparency in foreign aid including ‘Haiti: Where has all the money gone?’.

Bill Anderson, information architect, Development Initiatives, London @devinitorg
Bill works on African data revolution, joined-up data, global data standards and is a technical lead for International Aid Transparency Initiative (IATI).

Dina Abdel-Fattah, associate, Development Gateway, Washington DC @dgateway
Dina supports the Aid Management Platform in seven countries and was previously an Aid Management Fellow in Nepal.

Bibhusan Bista, CEO, YoungInnovations, Lalitpur, Nepal @BibhusanBista
Bibhusan is co-founder of a tech company based in Nepal that develops technology solutions for development challenges, promoting transparency and accountability.

Blair Glencorse, executive director, Accountability Lab, Washington, DC @blairglencorse
Blair is founder of Accountability Lab and has written about post-disaster efforts in Nepal.

Rupert Simons, CEO, Publish What You Fund, London, United Kingdom @RupertSimons
Rupert previously worked for the Tony Blair Africa Governance Initiative, most recently on the Sierra Leone Ebola response.

Leigh Mitchell, senior development effectiveness adviser, Ministry of National Planning and Economic Development, Nay Pyi Taw, Myanmar @leighhmitchell
Leigh advises the government of Myanmar on issues related to development effectiveness and aid transparency.

David Saldivar, Policy & Advocacy Manager, Oxfam America, Washington, DC, USA @davesaldivar
David leads Oxfam America’s policy work on aid transparency.

Alina Rocha Menocal, senior research fellow, Developmental Leadership Program, University of Birmingham, London UK @arochamenocal
Originally from Mexico, Alina is on secondment from the Overseas Development Institute. She leads a work-stream on political settlements and the politics of inclusion.

cards.title: Fruit bowls at the ready! / Share your still-life artworks now

item.title: Fruit bowls at the ready! Share your still-life artworks now
item.trailText: Bottles of ketchup, bunches of grapes? Or how about plain old flowers? Never forget the artistic potential of everyday objects ... send us your still-lifes now
item.standFirst:
Bottles of ketchup, bunches of grapes? Or how about plain old flowers? Never forget the artistic potential of everyday objects ... send us your still-lifes now

  • Your chance to be exhibited in London and New York: find out about our upcoming show
item.body:
One of art’s classic genres – the depiction of everyday objects – has been explored with fascinating results by contemporary artists, from Ori Gersht’s exploding floral arrangements to Peter Jones’s paintings of stuffed monkeys, Cindy Wright’s “Nature Morte” with a gutted fish in a bowl or Darren Jones’s clusters of 21st-century personal objects we accumulate when travelling.

Related: Still life photography: Jonathan Jones | Guardian photography guide

For our latest Share Your Art assignment, we want to see your takes on the genre. As our critic Jonathan Jones wrote: “The still life is democratic; anyone can do it. Pick up a pencil and draw your lunch, as the cartoonist Robert Crumb ritualistically does. Or take your camera and survey the ordinary things around you. Click the shutter on a bunch of grapes or a bottle of ketchup. Is that a still life?” The answer is complicated, especially in the era of Instagram and ubiquitous mobile photography. As always, you can interpret the theme in any way you like, and any materials are fine, from pen and ink to needlework or film. If you’d prefer to discuss your favourite still-life artworks, please do so in the comment thread.

If you need inspiration, take a look at this gallery of the 10 best contemporary still lifes, and at Jonathan Jones’s piece on still-life photography.

We’re getting excited about our forthcoming exhibitions in London and New York, where we’ll be showing the best of your submitted work. Click here for everything you need to know. It is important to note that we won’t accept more than three submissions per user for each assignment.

This project is open to everyone, but there are a few guidelines you need to follow if you’d like to submit your artwork.

How to share your artwork

Share an image of your artwork via GuardianWitness, by clicking the blue “contribute” button on this page, or via the Android or iPhone app. If you don’t have a Guardian profile, you’ll need to sign up. Then, find the Share Your Art assignment and follow the instructions to share your image. If you have any problems, email us at userhelp@theguardian.com.

We’ll feature some of our favourite submissions at theguardian.com/artanddesign and on Facebook. By sending us your pictures you: a) acknowledge that you have created the pictures or have permission to submit them; and b) grant us a non-exclusive, worldwide, free licence to publish your pictures as described. Copyright resides with you, and you may reuse your pictures however you wish. Read our full terms and conditions here.

Don’t worry if they don’t appear straight away – everything has to be approved before it can be “hung” in our online gallery. Tell us in the comments if there are any improvements we could make to the series.

cards.title: Q&A / We're five of Africa's most renowned writers – any questions for us?
cards.rawTitle: We're five of Africa's most renowned writers – any questions for us?

item.title: We're five of Africa's most renowned writers – any questions for us?
item.trailText: What is ‘African literature’? How easy is it to become an author on the continent? This year’s Caine prize shortlist join us for a live Q&A on Friday 3 July
item.standFirst: What is ‘African literature’? How easy is it to become an author on the continent? This year’s Caine prize shortlist join us for a live Q&A on Friday 3 July

blocks.title: What does it mean to be an African writer?
blocks.body:
Think African literature and who springs to mind? Chinua Achebe, “the father of modern African literature”? Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie, the writer whose voice was famously sampled in Beyoncé’s Flawless and recently sparked nationwide discussion on sexism in Nigeria.

But who else? Despite the talent of and calibre of African writers, most struggle to get the international recognition they deserve. The Caine Prize, now in its 16th year, seeks to remedy this with an annual celebration of the continent’s best writers.

Focused on short-stories the accolade has been awarded to some of the most prominent names from the continent today, including Kenya’s Binyavanga Wainaina, Sierra Leone’s Olufemi Terry and Zimbabwe’s NoViolet Bulawayo.

But why do African writers struggle to get noticed? Is the “African literature” grouping a help or hindrance? What, if anything, links these writers together? Is there really such as “African literature”?

We’ve asked the five shortlisted writers from this year’s Caine prize – Segun Afolabi, Elnathan John, FT Kola, Masande Ntshanga and Namwali Serpell – to join our panel to discuss these questions; offer tips for budding writers and talk about their work.

Any questions?

They’ll join us live on Friday 3 July March between 12.30-1.30pm BST, post your questions in the comments below or tweet them at @GuardianAfrica

item.title: Wildlife on your doorstep: July
item.trailText: June has arrived and the northern hemisphere wildlife will be looking forward to some decent summer weather, while the southern hemisphere wildlife will be preparing for winter. We’d like to see your photos of the June wildlife near you
item.standFirst:
It’s July and while the northern hemisphere is basking in warm summer temperatures, the southern hemisphere wildlife are in the midst of winter. We’d like to see your photos of the July wildlife near you

  • Readers’ June wildlife photos via GuardianWitness
item.body:
July is here and while the northern hemisphere wildlife will be making the most of the heatwaves and sunshine, their southern hemisphere counterparts are now at the mercy of winter. So what sort of wildlife will we all discover on our doorsteps? We’d like to see your photos of the July wildlife near you.

Share your photos and videos with us and we’ll feature our favourites on the Guardian site.

You can share your July wildlife photos, videos and stories with us by clicking on the blue ‘Contribute’ buttons. Or if you’re out and about you can download the GuardianWitness app or look for our assignments in the new Guardian app.
